title: Quickly change active webcam
content:
I have two webcams in my laptop labeled "Webcam_integrated" and "Webcam_peripheral". When visiting a site which require camera access (in my case google meet) A prompt will appear as usual to choose a camera.

Now let I choose "Webcam_integrated" and everything is good. Now what I want to do is to use "Webcam_peripheral" without reloading the page

Current Solution Currently I am doing this by disabling the video from google meet and again enable which will make firefox to ask for permission again and from there select another camera I want to use. But u can see this simple task however takes tens of seconds. So is there any way to do the same or some how achieve same result from possibly a keyboard shortcut. Or may be you could give idea to develop extension for this task?
creator: sudipghimire533

creator: hillbilly246

title: Missing Month
content:
I recently (19th of May) had to reinstall Linux. I thought I had everything backed up, but apparently I forgot to backup my Firefox profile.

I'd lost a few years of bookmarks and my current session, but c'est la vie, back up better next time. I *did* have Firefox Sync, but after checking the support forums saying Sync is not a backup tool, I'd lost hope.

I *did* have an older device, so I booted that up to get up to about 18 months ago. But when I did so, I was able to get history and bookmarks up to the 14th of April (this year), despite not booting that device since long before then.

I'm not looking a gift horse in the mouth, but where did this come from, and could the other 4 weeks be hiding there?
creator: adam_nawal

title: Firefox Insecurity?
content:
I had been using Firefox for years for privacy, but I found a blog circulating on Reddit which is ran by a security researcher who claims to debunk misinformation about security. One article is about Firefox and Chromium security[1] and the author claims that Firefox is lacking in its security, so much so that they advise people to stick to Chromium[2]. I can’t make heads or tails of it but (at least from a layman’s point of view) they seem to know what they are talking about. At the very end they even include other security researchers who seem to share the same opinion. The only potential flaw I found in the article is that they claim Firefox lacks site isolation, which seems to be true at the moment, but since Fission is now available on Firefox it looks like that will no longer be true in the near-future. However they did claim that Fission still has leaks, which might indicate that it is still a security concern.

I came to ask what others thought of these criticisms and see if they hold water. If so, does Mozilla have plans on improving the security of Firefox? In my opinion, most of Firefox’s user base is made of people who care about privacy, security, and freedom. If it’s true that Firefox has poor security, I think securing Firefox should be one of Mozilla’s top priorities before trying to add new features or create a fancier UI to appeal to the general public.

[1] https://madaidans-insecurities.github.io/firefox-chromium.html [2] https://madaidans-insecurities.github.io/security-privacy-advice.html
creator: nacknack
